Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Ultra-large and low-cost electrodynamic modeling in commercial clouds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to enable anyone with internet to access extremely powerful computing facilities to perform scientific computing. High performance computing is essential for computational prototyping in many areas of modern engineering, such as solar cells, automobiles, aerospace, and communication devices. However, significant barriers make it difficult for ordinary engineers to easily access powerful computing facilities. By leveraging the low-cost commercial cloud, the project will develop key technology that allow commercial clouds to perform extremely high performance scientific computing, thereby significantly reducing the cost and increasing the accessibility of high performance computing.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop technologies that overcome key challenges in using commercial clouds for high performance computing. Unlike high performance computers, commercial clouds are not designed for scientific computing. They have high latency, intermitted availability, and heterogeneously distributed resources. These features make it difficult to conduct scientific computing. This project will develop new computing methods that fully take into account the heterogeneous nature of the commercial cloud. It enables anyone to access high performance scientific computing anywhere with an easy-to-use interface. Computing is provided as on-demand service. Engineers would not need to own any high performance computers and the computing resources are virtually unlimited.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the NSF Phase I STTR Project “Ultra?large and low?cost electrodynamic modeling in commercial Clouds”, FlexCompute, Inc has developed novel algorithms for performing scientific modeling on cloud architectures such as Amazon EC2 and Google Compute Engine. FlexCompute’s technology allows engineers to perform resource-intensive computation without the need to invest in costly clusters or gain access to supercomputers. Instead, they simply go to FlexCompute’s website (www.simulation.cloud) and upload input files describing the physical description of their simulation. The vast resources available in the cloud allow users to upload and run a virtually unlimited number of simulation at once. This greatly increases productivity for critical design simulations, slashing time-to-result. Additionally, users only pay for the processing they need, when they need it. For most computational engineers, this is far more economic than running a private cluster 24/7.

 

FlexCompute’s algorithms have demonstrated the ability to cut simulation time by as much as three orders of magnitude relative to un-modified solvers. Interfaces have been built-in to four open-source solvers (MPB, MEEP, S4, and OpenFOAM) to enable high-throughput performance in the cloud and are hosted on simulation.cloud. Furthermore, a custom post-processing interface has been developed for OpenFOAM, in which real time in-situ data analysis is performed and streamed to the user’s web browser.
